content: The Act titled "Examination of Exposures to Environmental Hazards During Military Service and Health Care for Atsugi Naval Air Facility Veterans and their Families Act of 2014" establishes an Advisory Board on Environmental Exposures at Atsugi Naval Air Facility. The Act establishes an Advisory Board on Environmental Exposures at Atsugi Naval Air Facility, with seven members appointed to provide expert advice on exposure to environmental hazards at the facility. The Advisory Board on Environmental Exposures at Atsugi Naval Air Facility consists of seven members appointed based on specific criteria, including military service organization members, federal agency officials with environmental exposure experience, and scientists with relevant backgrounds. The Advisory Board members are appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, serve three-year terms renewable up to six years, fill vacancies in the same manner as original appointments, select a Chairperson for a one-year term, require a majority for a quorum, and meet at the Chairperson's call. Compensation details are outlined for federal government officers. The Advisory Board members are appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, serve three-year terms renewable up to six years, fill vacancies in the same manner as original appointments, select a Chairperson for a one-year term, require a majority for a quorum, and meet at the Chairperson's call. Members of the Board who are federal government employees cannot receive additional pay but will receive travel expenses. Non-government employee members will be compensated from funds allocated for the title's purposes. Advisory Board members are paid at the highest rate under title 5, United States Code, while performing duties and receive per diem, travel, and transportation expenses during necessary travel. The Advisory Board members are paid at the highest rate under title 5, United States Code, with a limitation of 120 days compensation in a calendar year. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and other necessary personnel without following civil service laws, and fix their compensation without regard to chapter 51 provisions. The Advisory Board can request personnel from federal departments to assist without reimbursement. The Board will terminate 12 years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. CONSIDERATION OF ENVIRONMENTAL EXPOSURES AT ATSUGI NAVAL AIR FACILITY, JAPAN. The Advisory Board established under section 3 will study cases of exposure to environmental hazards at Atsugi Naval Air Facility in Japan since 1983, caused by contamination from an incinerator. It will evaluate claims related to hazardous exposures submitted by members of the Armed Forces, veterans, dependants, advocacy groups, and officials from the Department of Defense and Veterans Affairs. The Advisory Board will consider exposure claims from members of the Armed Forces. Within 180 days, they will either convene a science review panel to assess exposure extent, recommend no further consideration, or report findings to the Secretaries of Defense and Veterans Affairs. The Advisory Board will submit recommendations to the Secretaries of Defense and Veterans Affairs regarding health care benefits or compensation for members of the Armed Forces exposed to environmental hazards. The Advisory Board may convene a science advisory panel consisting of seven scientists to assist in considering claims related to exposure to environmental hazards by members of the Armed Forces. The panel will provide information on cost and exposure as defined in regulations prescribed by the Act. The subsection outlines the criteria for the seven scientists on the science advisory panel, who must have backgrounds in environmental exposure or assessments and not be federal government officials. The Chairperson of the Advisory Board selects the panel's Chairperson from its members for a one-year term. The panel must submit a report with recommendations on military exposure claims within 180 days of being requested by the Advisory Board. The Advisory Board may recommend further study or compensation for military exposure claims. The Board and science advisory panels have subpoena authority for testimony. The Advisory Board has subpoena authority to require witness testimony for hazardous environmental exposure cases. Federal agencies must cooperate with the Advisory Board. The Advisory Board will terminate 12 years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. HEALTH CARE SERVICES FOR CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS AT ATSUGI NAVAL AIR FACILITY, JAPAN. The Secretary of Defense, in coordination with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, must establish procedures to identify individuals exposed to environmental hazards at Atsugi Naval Air Facility, Japan, due to contamination from an incinerator. Those on the list will be immediately eligible for health care benefits. The Secretary of Defense, in coordination with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, will provide health care benefits to current and former members of the Armed Forces exposed to contaminants from an incinerator at Atsugi Naval Air Facility. The Secretary of Defense, in coordination with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, will submit a report to the relevant committees detailing the evidence and criteria used to determine exposure to contaminants at Atsugi Naval Air Facility. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REPORT. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, must submit an annual report to the Committees on Armed Services and Veterans' Affairs of the Senate and House of Representatives on health care and benefits provided under the Act. The report will include details on individuals receiving benefits, healthcare provided, and procedures for identifying those exposed to environmental hazards at Atsugi Naval. The annual report must include details on individuals receiving benefits and healthcare provided under the Act, as well as procedures for identifying those exposed to environmental hazards at Atsugi Naval Air Facility, Japan. Recommendations for additional legislation may also be included. The Secretaries of Defense and Veterans Affairs will create regulations for the Act, including guidelines for health conditions from exposures at Atsugi Naval Air Facility, Japan. Appropriations are authorized for Act implementation.
